title: About
text:
About this site

predict(lm.fit, data.frame(lstat = c(5, 10, 15)), interval = "confidence") #  This function can be used to produce confidence and prediction intervals. Here, the numeric values are for prediction
predict(lm.fit, data.frame(lstat = c(5, 10, 15)), interval = "prediction")
plot(lstat, medv)
abline(lm.fit, lwd = 3) # lwd increases the width of the regression line by a factor of three (3). This works for plot() and lines() function too.
abline(lm.fit, col = "red")

title: Abdoulie Jallow
text: Hello! I’m Abdoulie, but most people know me as Jallow. I hold a bachelor’s degree in biological chemistry and have a deep passion for science, Popperian epistemology, and lifelong learning. I admire thinkers like Karl Popper, David Deutsch, and Nick Lane. This website is my space to document and share my learning journey. Feel free to explore and see what I’m working on!

title: A Quarto Thesis Template for Bachelor and Diploma Projects at JKU
text: This template is based on the Masters/Doctoral Thesis, LaTeX Template, Version 2.5 (27 Aug 2017), which Eli Holmes updated for Quarto. I further modified the Quarto template to fulfill JKU’s criteria for diploma theses and doctoral dissertations. Using Quarto was motivated by the difficulties I had when writing my first bachelor thesis in Microsoft Word. These include ensuring consistent citation formatting, text alignment, and maintaining a tidy version-controlled workflow. Quarto tackles these issues and also allows data analysis with R and documentation to be done on a single platform, hence improving reproducibility.

title: A Quarto Thesis Template for Bachelor and Diploma Projects at JKU
text:
1. Clone the Template
Navigate to the directory where you want to create your thesis files. Run the following command in a terminal to download the template and its associated folders:

quarto use template jallow-code/jku-quarto-thesis

You will be prompted to specify an empty directory name for the template files. Provide a name for the new directory, which will store your thesis files.

title: A Quarto Thesis Template for Bachelor and Diploma Projects at JKU
text:
2. Render the Template
Once the template is installed, change into the new directory:

cd <new-directory-name>

To generate the document, use the command:

quarto render


Troubleshooting Errors
If you encounter the following error during rendering:

ERROR: 
compilation failed - missing packages (automatic install disabled)
LaTeX Error: Something's wrong--perhaps a missing \item.

See the LaTeX manual or LaTeX Companion for explanation.
Type  H <return>  for immediate help.
 ...
l.872 \end{CSLReferences}
This error is likely due to outdated versions of Quarto or TinyTeX. To resolve it:

Update your TinyTex installation.
Ensure you are using the latest version of Quarto.

title: A Quarto Thesis Template for Bachelor and Diploma Projects at JKU
text:
Thesis Type and Frontmatter
The template is configured for a Bachelor’s thesis by default. To change this, edit the _quarto.yml file. For example:

thesis:
  type: Bachelor Thesis # Or "Master Thesis", "Doctoral Dissertation", etc.
  degree-name: Bachelor of Science
  group: Biological Chemistry # name of your study program
  supervisor:
    primary: "Assoz. Univ.-Prof. Dr. Ian Teasdale"
    co: "Dipl.-Ing. Michael Kneidinger"
  university: Johannes Kepler Universität Linz
  department: Institute of Polymer Chemistry
  faculty: Faculty of Engineering and Natural Sciences
You can also customize elements of the front matter (e.g., acknowledgments, dedication) by commenting out or modifying the respective sections in_quarto.yml. For instance, to exclude the dedication page:

# dedication: "Frontmatter/dedication.tex"

title: A Quarto Thesis Template for Bachelor and Diploma Projects at JKU
text:
Adding Symbols or Abbreviations
The Frontmatter folder contains LaTeX files for abbreviations, symbols, and other sections. If needed, search online for LaTeX code examples to add symbols or format abbreviations.
